mechanoreception.notes: Bivalves possess mechanoreceptors for sensing touch and pressure, crucial for burrowing, predator avoidance (detecting vibrations), and maintaining position in sediment. Inferred from the ability of cockles to burrow and 'jump'.

chemoreception.notes: Cockles use chemoreception to detect food particles (plankton) in the water and for communication. The mantle has inhalant and exhalant siphons, enabling the animal to detect dissolved chemicals in the surrounding water.
